docs.abstract: Two decades ago, a renowned professor promised to produce a flawless version of one of the 20th century’s most celebrated novels: “Ulysses.” Then he disappeared.
docs.snippet: Two decades ago, a renowned professor promised to produce a flawless version of one of the 20th century’s most celebrated novels: “Ulysses.” Then he disappeared.
docs.lead_paragraph: Some 16 years ago, The Boston Globe published an article about a jobless man who haunted Marsh Plaza, at the center of Boston University. The picture showed a curious figure in a long overcoat, hunched beneath a black fedora near the central sculpture. He spent his days talking with pigeons to whom he had given names: Checkers and Wingtip and Speckles. The article could have been just another human-interest story about our society’s failing commitment to mental health, except that the man crouched in conversation with the birds was John Kidd, once celebrated as the greatest James Joyce scholar alive.

headline.main: The Strange Case of the Missing Joyce Scholar

docs.abstract: Should you force a loved one to gaze upon something so horrifying?
docs.snippet: Should you force a loved one to gaze upon something so horrifying?
docs.lead_paragraph: Shannon writes: My husband, Nathan, refuses to be in the same room as a piece of art I own. It’s a web of smiling baby-doll heads stitched together with embroidery thread. It’s about three feet in diameter and bulges pleasingly out from the wall of my office. Please order him to face the art and gaze upon it for one minute with all the lights on.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on a Nightmarish Work of Art
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: Some writers draw you so far into their voices that it makes you want to join in, and write alongside them.
docs.snippet: Some writers draw you so far into their voices that it makes you want to join in, and write alongside them.
docs.lead_paragraph: — From “Afterglow (a dog memoir)” (Grove Press, 2017, Page 191), by Eileen Myles, the author of 20 books of poetry and prose.

docs.abstract: Can there be too many butts?
docs.snippet: Can there be too many butts?
docs.lead_paragraph: Annie writes: I want my cousin-in-law Alejandro to tone down his posting of dudes’ derrières on social media. The bums in question belong to strangers, friends and, occasionally, to Alejandro. I could unfollow him, but that seems extreme. Please order that every booty photo needs a cute baby animal superimposed on top of it. I suggest a wombat.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Proper Posting Habits
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: What sort of baked goods do we owe our significant others?
docs.snippet: What sort of baked goods do we owe our significant others?
docs.lead_paragraph: Kate writes: I have been asking my boyfriend, Brian, for a fun, fancy birthday cake for 10 years. I’ve relaxed the definition over time to include prefab cakes, like Carvel’s Cookie Puss. But he has never done it. I’m turning 40. Please order Brian to provide a custom-made fun, fancy cake.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Birthday Cakes, Erotic and Otherwise
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: For the actress Ellen Page and the choreographer Emma Portner, physicality is itself a form of art.
docs.snippet: For the actress Ellen Page and the choreographer Emma Portner, physicality is itself a form of art.
docs.lead_paragraph: For the actress Ellen Page and the choreographer Emma Portner, physicality is itself a form of art.

Ava writes: I am a teenager, and I need my nutrition. My stepmom refuses to let me eat in her car. I understand: Her seats are white, and I am a messy eater. But she recently installed a dog-proof seat cover for the entire back seat. When the dog uses it, he leaves it covered in hair and dirt. No one but me and the dog ever sits there. But she still refuses to let me eat in the car, even on the cover specifically designed to protect the seat! Can you please order her to let me eat in her car?

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Teenagers Eating in Cars
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: What makes a pun a pun?
docs.snippet: What makes a pun a pun?
docs.lead_paragraph: Chris writes: My wife and I disagree on whether the Def Leppard song title “Armageddon It” is a pun. I insist that it is, at best, a moronic misspelling. She says that it fits the definition of a pun whether or not I think it’s funny. Does it?

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on a Vexing Glam-Metal Lyric
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman
